original_title: Manhattan: South William Street - Broad Street
text:
South William Street, east from (No. 34), but not including Broad, to but not including William Street, showing the New York Cotton Exchange Building (with cone shaped roof-corner) which is situated at the S.E. corner of William and Beaver Streets. Most of these buildings still remain up to the present day (1937) with the exception of Nos. 34 to 28 (three houses in the left foreground) which were replaced by the 35-story International Telephone Building and the 4-story house, seen in the centre background, whose site is now occupied by the 11-story building of the Lehman Bros. banking house. The New York Cotton Exchange Building was also razed and was supplanted by a new 24-story modern skyscraper which is the Exchange's new home.

About 1900.

Brown Brothers.

Broad Street, north from South William Street. The low buildings on the right were replaced in 1929 by the 35 story International Telephone Building. (No. 67 Broad Street). Shown in the center are tall structures that from left to right.are, the 17 story Johnston Building (subsequently the 48 story Continental Building), the 16 story Mackay (Commercial Cable Co.) Buildings an: the 21 story Broad Exchange Building. The dome seen is atop the Gillenden Building, a structure demolished in 1910 and replaced by the present Bankers Trust Company Building. The 10 story structure at the left is No. 88-64 Broad Street and is at the N.W.corner of Beaver Street. In 1922 this is listed as occupied by the White Oil Company.
April 1906
George L. Balgue

Broad Street, north from South William Street. The low buildings on the right were replaced in 1929 by the 35 story International Telephone Building. (No. 67 Broad Street). Shown in the center are tall structures that from left to right, are, the 17 story Johnston Building (subsequently the 48 story Continental Building), the 16 story Mackay (Commercial Cable Co.) Buildings and the 21 story Broad Exchange Building. The dome seen is atop the Gillenden Building, a structure demolished in 1910 and replaced by the present Bankers Trust Company Building. The 10 story structure at the left is No. 68-64 Broad Street and is at the N.W. corner of Beaver Street. In 1922 this is listed as occupied by the White Oil Company.

April 1906

George L. Balgue

A general view of the easterly side of the downtown Manhattan sector in the Wall Street vicinity, as photographed northeastward from the Produce Exchange Bldg. The East River, the Brooklyn Bridge, and the Brooklyn shore are in the background. Thru the center foreground runs South William Street, traversing the short distance from Broad to William Streets. At that point appears the New York Cotton Exchange Bldg.

February 4, 1927

New York Edison Co.
title: General view - Downtown Manhattan - Wall Street.

text:
67 Broad Street, east side, from South William to Beaver Streets. This location is that of the 35 storied International Telephone Bldg. which appears in both views with flag atop. To the right in view 2, is the tower atop the Standard Oil Bldg. The photographer is viewing westward along Beaver Street from the 35 stories Wall and Hanover (Brown Bros.) Bldg. Note: in the background beyond Battery Park, the Upper Bay, the Statue of Liberty and the Jersey Shore.

June 26, 1929.
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

67 Broad Street, east side, from South William to Beaver Streets. This location is that of the 35 storied International Telephone Bldg. which appears in both views with flag atop. To the right in view 2, is the tower atop the Standard Oil Bldg. The photographer is viewing westward along Beaver Street from the 35 stories Wall and Hanover (Brown Bros.) Bldg. Note: in the background beyond Battery Park, the Upper Bay, the Statue of Liberty and the Jersey Shore.

June 26, 1929.
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

81-71 Broad Street, at, adjoining, and north of the N.E. corner of South William Street. These buildings are being wrecked to give way to the South William Street portion of the International Telephone and Telegraph Building, the first half of which is shown in the background.

May 12, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
85-99 Broad Street, east side, from South William to Pearl streets. On the left is the All-American Cables Building; at the extreme right is Fraunces' Tavern.
June 13, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, a year later.
July 8, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
85-99 Broad Street, east side, from South William to Pearl streets. On the left is the All-American Cables Building; at the extreme right is Fraunces' Tavern.
June 13, 1929.

original_title: Manhattan: South William Street - Broad Street
text:
37-33 and 31-25 South William Street, adjoining and east of the S.E. corner of Broad Street, as seen across clearance at the N.E. corner (site of the present (1937) International Telephone Building).
June 13, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: South William Street - Broad Street
text:
(1)

43 to 9 South William Street, south side, east from Broad Street, to Mill Lane, showing (foreground) construction work in progress on the 35-story International Telephone Building at the N.E. corner of Broad Street. Contiguous to, and eastward from the construction work, are seen the roof tops of six 4-story houses, Nos. 26 to 14 South William Street. Also shown is a general view eastward of the surrounding area, with the East River and Brooklyn Bridge in the background. This view was taken from the Produce Exchange Building on Broadway, between Stone and Beaver Streets.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, a more limited view. Also shown (centre foreground) is No. 89-85 Broad Street, east side, between Stone (right) and South William Streets. This 8-story building bears also Nos. 25-29 Stone and No. 43-39 South William Streets. On the extreme right are buildings at the S.E. corner of Stone and Broad Streets.

August 28, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

original_title: Manhattan: South William Street - Broad Street
text:
(1)

43 to 9 South William Street, south side, east from Broad Street, to Mill Lane, showing (foreground) construction work in progress on the 35-story International Telephone Building at the N.E. corner of Broad Street. Contiguous to, and eastward from the construction work, are seen the roof tops of six 4-story houses, Nos. 26 to 14 South William Street. Broad Street, west side, north from, but not including, South William Street. In the centre background, the 50-story Irving Trust Company Building is nearing completion.
August 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Broad Street, north from, but not including, South William Street. The Beaver Street side of the International Telephone and Telegraph Building has been completed, and work is about to start on the South William Street portion.
August 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, but including South William Street, a year later. The second half of the International Telephone and Telegraph Building is now completed. In the background looms the skeleton of the 60 Wall Street tower.
August 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Broad Street, north from, but not including, South William Street. The Beaver Street side of the International Telephone and Telegraph Building has been completed, and work is about to start on the South William Street portion.
August 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, but including South William Street, a year later. The second half of the International Telephone and Telegraph Building is now completed. In the background looms the skeleton of the 60 Wall Street tower.
August 6, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

Herald Tribune Editorial Art Dept.
A.I.E. Lefcourt's latest building achievement --- the new $7,000,000 International Telephone Building which opens it doors next Tuesday, May 1st, with every square foot of space leased, establishing an unparalleled leasing record.
67 Broad Street
No date
